title: Influence of a Circuit Breaker's Grading Capacitor on Controlled Transformer Switching
abstract: Controlled switching, taking into account the residual flux level within a transformer core, can effectively eliminate inrush currents. Many switching sequences assume the residual flux as a constant value, which can be obtained by a measurement after a transformer de-energization. However, in case of a transformer system that is switched by a circuit breaker equipped with a grading capacitor, the residual flux characteristic cannot be considered as constant. A source voltage will feed the deenergized transformer system through the grading capacitor, which will change the residual flux level and let oscillations appear. It follows that the optimal re-energization targets change and inrush currents might not be optimally minimized. Further, transient voltages based on line failures can influence the residual flux through a grading capacitor as well. At first, this paper evaluates the influence of a grading capacitor on the residual flux characteristic analytically. Further, measurements of two transformer systems at a varied de-energization instant and for different grading capacitors provide actual information for the development of future controller systems.

1. Introduction
The residual ﬂux within a transformer core not only de-
pends on transformer speciﬁcations but also on transformer
equipments as a circuit breaker’s grading capacitor and its
chopping level. Previous work from CIGRE
(1) reported,
based on the simulation result in Refs. (2) (3), that the resid-
ual ﬂux within a no-loaded transformer core can be aﬀected
by the power ﬂow through a circuit breaker’ grading capaci-
tor. This paper veriﬁes now the reported phenomena based
on measurements and a mathematical evaluation, because
an actual dynamic magnetic-current simulation after a trans-
former de-energization is very diﬃcult to perform. Further,
the residual ﬂux characteristic of diﬀerent transformer sys-
tems at a varied de-energization instant has to be described
in order to provide the scientiﬁc information for the devel-
opment of future controller systems. Therefore, this paper
provides de-energization measurements of two transformer
systems with a varied grading capacitor and especially points
out its inﬂuence on controlled transformer switching.

compared to a system with only one chamber. Similar ca-

breaking chamber. Regarding Ref. (4), 200 pF was written
to be a characteristic value for a grading capacitor across a

4. Inﬂuence on Controlled Transformer Switch-
ing
4.1 Switching Theories Hysteresis loops as illus-
trated in Figs. 2 and 10 indicate at the current-ﬂux peak the
saturation characteristic of the hysteresis loops. Regarding
that during steady-state condition a transformer is usually
used up to its saturation level, the energization instant of a no-
loaded transformer systems becomes important. A complete
random energization can lead to very large inrush currents.
Several controlled switching strategies, taking into account
the residual ﬂux level within a transformer core, have been
deﬁned in order to reduce these inrush currents
(11)–(13) .T h e
optimal re-energization target is when the prospective ﬂux
from the source side is identical to the residual ﬂux. If the
residual ﬂux level at the re-energization instant does not cor-
respond to the ﬂux from the source side, the superimposed
ﬂux inside the transformer core will drift into the saturation
characteristic and inrush currents will occur.
4.2 Eﬀect of the Grading Capacitor on Inrush Cur-
rents An exemplary, optimal re-energization of a single-
phase transformer system is illustrated in Fig. 11. The os-
cillations after the de-energization instant are based on the
power ﬂow through the circuit breakers grading capacitances.
In addition, the ﬂux decay can be observed as well. Figure 12
enlarges the re-energization instant of Fig. 11 and regarding
the deﬁnition of the optimal re-energization target, several
crossings of the prospective ﬂux from the source and the
residual ﬂux would fulﬁll this condition. However, the opti-
mal re-energization targets for a circuit breaker with grading
capacitor diﬀer to a circuit breaker without grading capacitor
and future transformer systems have to consider these phe-
nomena.
4.3 Line Faults After a Transformer Deenergization
If a power ﬂow through the grading capacitances is en-
abled, line faults and its clearing operation inﬂuence the
residual ﬂux level and therefore the optimal re-energization
target of a no-loaded transformer as well—An exemplary
measurement is illustrated in Fig. 13.

5. Conclusion and Outlook
The investigation on the ﬂux behavior could reveal the in-
ﬂuence of a grading capacitor on the residual ﬂux by mea-
surements and mathematical analysis: A larger grading ca-
pacitor increases the micro oscillation’s amplitude and de-
creases the residual ﬂux. The ratio between these phenom-
ena have been measured as constant at any de-energization
instant and therefore mainly depend on the grading capacitor
and the hysteretic characteristic of a transformer core. These
two phenomena will become strong for a comparably large
grading capacitor. The residual ﬂux behavior will directly af-
fect the optimal re-energization targets of a no-loaded trans-
former system, because the locked in residual ﬂux can not
anymore be assumed as stable.
As a next step the eﬀect of a 3-phase transformer connec-
tion on these phenomena shall be evaluated. Further, a de-
tailed investigation on the residual ﬂux behavior can improve
the residual ﬂux estimation and might provide a sophisticated
transformer model used for controlled switching analysis.
